titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the A. R. Gurney Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 05:27

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The A. R. Gurney Papers document the life and career of American playwright and novelist A. R. Gurney and consist of correspondence, writings, printed material, and photographs.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 38 (digital media): Restricted fragile material. Access copies of digital files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 42 (audiovisual materials): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of A. R. Gurney (Yale School of Drama 1958), 2004, 2012, 2016.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: I. Writings, 1958-1991. II. Correspondence, 1962-1978. III. Printed Material, undated. IV. Other Material, undated. V. October 2012 Acquisition, circa 1960s-2009. VI. October 2016 Acquisition, 1947-2016.

bioghist.head: A. R. Gurney (1930-2017)
bioghist.p: American author Albert Ramsdell Gurney was born on November 1, 1930 in Buffalo, New York, to Albert Ramsdell and Marion Spaulding Gurney. He obtained a Bachelor of Arts from Williams College (1952) and Master of Fine Arts from the Yale School of Drama (1958). The Yale School of Drama produced Gurney's first work, a musical titled Love in Buffalo , the year he graduated.

Following graduation Gurney taught English and Latin at a day school in Belmont, Massachusetts (1959-1960) and then joined the Massachusetts Institute of Technology as a Professor of Humanities (1960-1996) and Professor of Literature (1970-1996). Gurney has written a number of plays, screenplays, and novels. Children (1974), The Dining Room (1982), and Love Letters (1988) are among his best known plays. His screenplays include The House of Mirth (1972) and Sylvia (1995). Gurney's novels are: The Gospel According to Joe (1974), Entertaining Strangers (1977), The Snow Ball (1984), and Early American (1996).
Gurney married Mary Forman Goodyear on June 8, 1957. They have four children: George, Amy, Evelyn, and Benjamin.
Gurney passed away on June 13, 2017, in New York City.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: A. R. Gurney Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and in some instances minimal organization.

The finding aid for this collection is compiled from a preliminary list for the acquisition that was created at or around the time of receipt by the library. The preliminary list was migrated to comply with current archival descriptive standards in 2007-2008. As part of the migration, modifications were made to the formatting of the list; however, the content of the list was neither modified nor verified.

As a rule, descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The A. R. Gurney Papers document the life and career of American playwright and novelist A. R. Gurney and consist of correspondence, writings, printed material, and photographs dating from roughly 1947 to 2016.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The A. R. Gurney Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into five subseries: Plays, Translations and Adaptations, Screenplays and Teleplays, Novels, Criticism, Essays, and Other Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I contains playscripts, screenplays, teleplays, and novels in draft form in addition to production files and translations of Gurney's writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

A Program for the Close Reading of Thornton Wilder's "Our Town"

arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II contains incoming and outgoing correspondence.

arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III contains printed material such as playbills, posters, and other printed ephemera relating to productions of Gurney's works.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: Correspondence, Personal papers, Writings, and Performance and event recordings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials within this series maintain the original physical organization found at time of acquisition.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence between A. R. Gurney and his family members, collaborators, and other acquaintances, along with photographs and ephemera sometimes included with the correspondence. The material documents personal and business relationships related to A. R. Gurney.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials within this series are organized chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains yearbooks, event programs, certificates, and other materials related to A. R. Gurney's life and work.

did.unittitle: Antony and Cleopatra souvenir program, autographed by Katharine Cornell
Program for Zanuck in the Streets
Souvenir program for 25th reunion of Williams College Class of 1952
Program for St. Paul's School 50th Reunion
City of Buffalo proclamations in honor of A.R. Gurney

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this series are arranged alphabetically by work title, with the exception of uncollected notes, which are located at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains playscripts, notes, clippings, photographs, correspondence, and other ephemera related to A. R. Gurney's writings.

did.unittitle: Central Park West script and notes
Love Letters program from Polish production
Photographs from performances including Love Letters
Casting info and program for the Signature Theater
Strawberry Fields piano and vocal score
Sylvia programs and posters from international productions
Wayside Motor Inn notes and casting information

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials in this series are arranged alphabetically by performance or event title.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains video recordings of theatrical productions of works by A.R. Gurney, along with recordings of events related to Gurney's life, work, and interests.

accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
